title: resurrection
comment: The raising of Jesus Christ from the dead by God after his suffering and death on the cross. Historical evidence for his resurrection includes the empty tomb and the appearance of the risen Christ to the disciples. It has significance both in relation to the identity of Jesus Christ and the future hope of believers.

children.title: resurrection, of Jesus Christ
children.comment: The resurrection of Jesus Christ is of central importance to the NT. It affirms the divinity of Jesus Christ, marks the words and deeds of his ministry with God's seal of approval and opens the way to the future resurrection of believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's resurrection was foreshadowed in the OT
Jesus Christ's resurrection was predicted
In the OT
By Jesus Christ himself
Jesus Christ's resurrection was anticipated by the raising of the dead
In the OT

primaryrefs.comment: None of the OT or NT miracles are true resurrections. Those raised resumed life as before, their bodies unchanged. Resurrection for Jesus Christ and therefore for his people means a changed body and permanent life in glory. This is the ``better resurrection''.

children.title: In the miracles of Jesus Christ
The sequence of events in Jesus Christ's resurrection
It was preceded by suffering and death
It took place on the first day of the week
It was announced by angels
The disciples were reluctant to believe it
The disciples saw the evidence and were ultimately convinced
The risen Christ appeared to many people

secondaryrefs.comment: to two on the Emmaus road

children.title: The resurrection was followed by Jesus Christ's entry into glory
Jesus Christ's resurrection body was spiritual but not ghostly
resurrection, significance of Jesus Christ's
children.comment: Jesus Christ's resurrection represents a demonstration of the power of God, the confirmation of the divinity of Jesus Christ and the grounds of hope for Christian believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's resurrection was a demonstration of God's power
The power of God the Father
The power of the Holy Spirit
The resurrection confirmed Jesus Christ as the Son of God

primaryrefs.comment: John calls Jesus Christ's miracles ``signs'' (see also Jn 2:11; 6:2) and his resurrection is the climax, confirming his identity beyond all doubt

children.title: The centrality of the resurrection of Jesus Christ
As the basis of faith
As the basis of believers' justification
As the basis of Christian hope
As the basis of believers' resurrection

primaryrefs.comment: The Law of Moses (Ex 23:16) provided for an offering of the firstfruits of crops to God. The firstfruits were the guarantee of the full harvest to come. The NT sees the resurrection of Jesus Christ as the firstfruits of the full ingathering of all God's people when Jesus Christ comes again.

children.title: resurrection, spiritual
children.comment: The gospel brings new life to men and women, who lived in death and darkness until they came to faith. The NT emphasis upon ``being made alive in Christ'' is closely linked to the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Being made alive in Christ
Crossing over from death to life
Believers continue to live by the power of the risen Christ

Spiritual desires
Spiritual assurance
Spiritual appetite
Commitment to God
Love for fellow believers
Spiritual character
resurrection, of the dead
children.comment: Scripture speaks of a general resurrection of all people at the end of time, which will be followed by judgment.

resurrection, of believers
children.comment: The future event of finally being raised to glory with Jesus Christ. Believers may rest assured that, on account of their faith, they will share in the resurrection and glory of Christ and be with him for ever.

children.title: The nature of the resurrection of believers
A resurrection to eternal life
Being completely united to Jesus Christ
It leads to becoming like Jesus Christ
The resurrection as the future hope of believers

primaryrefs.comment: In the NT the death of believers is often likened to sleep.

children.title: The resurrection as an incentive to godliness and perseverance
The resurrection as an incentive to endurance of suffering
